abstract.p: The acceleration output of an electro-hydraulic servo system corresponding to a sinusoidal input contains higher harmonics besides the fundamental input, because of complex nonlinearities occurring in the system. This causes harmonic distortion of the acceleration signal. The method for harmonic elimination based on adaptive notch filter is proposed here. The task is accomplished by generating a reference signal with a frequency that should be eliminated from the output. The reference input is filtered in such a way that it closely matches the harmonic. The filtered reference signal is added to the fundamental signal such that the output harmonic is cancelled leaving the desired signal alone. The weights of the adaptive filter are adjusted by the error between the input and the feedback acceleration to eliminate acceleration harmonic, creating an adaptive notch filter. The above concept is used as a basis for the development of an acceleration harmonic cancellation algorithm. Results of simulation and experiment on an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table demonstrate the efficiency and validity of the proposed control scheme.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: For an electro-hydraulic servo system, which includes mechanical and electronic systems, there are various nonlinearities, such as dead-zone, friction, backlash, and so on. Because of those nonlinear phenomena, the acceleration output of the system, corresponding to a sinusoidal input, contains harmonics with frequencies that are integer multiples of the fundamental frequency besides the fundamental, causing the acceleration harmonic distortion (Yao et al., 2008, 2009). This problem is especially prominent in acceleration control for real application, for example, an electro-hydraulic servo shaking table (Yao et al., 2010).

The dead-zone is a nonlinearity in which the output is zero until the magnitude of the input exceeds a certain value. It commonly exists in hydraulic servo valves. Gang and Petar (1994) designed a model reference adaptive controller for the control of plants with an unknown dead-zone, and investigated several control strategies. Recker (1997) presented an indirect adaptive output feedback control and applied to discrete time systems containing a dead-zone nonlinearity and linear dynamics.Avinash et al. (2001) investigated nonlinear systems with an unknown sandwiched dead-zone between the linear dynamic blocks in a hydraulic valve system, and proposed an adaptive hybrid control system combined with an adaptive dead-zone inverse for control of such systems to cancel the dead-zone effect, employing an inner-loop discrete-timed feedback and an outer-loop continuous-time feedback. Bessa et al. (2010) developed an adaptive fuzzy controller for nonlinear systems subject to dead-zone input and proved the boundedness of all closed-loop signals and the convergence properties of the tracking error using Lyapunov stability theory and Barbalat's lemma. Knokl and Unbehauen (2000) investigated a hydraulic system with a 4/3 way proportional valve which has a large dead-zone, and developed adaptive position control using artificialneural networks for compensation of the input nonlinearity.

For a hydraulic system, friction including viscous, Coulomb, and Stribeck friction, occurs in the movement between joints and in hydraulic cylinders. It can cause steady state and tracking error, which may result in a limited cycle, so friction has become one of the greatest obstacles in high-precision position tracking system. Papadopoulos and Chasparis (2002) developed a feedback model-based compensation of friction for servo-mechanism set-point and tracking tasks based on the test of a basic friction model and its influence on system response using describing function analysis.Friction identification and modeling is usually needed as the first step towards compensation for the friction effects. Zyada and Fukuda (2001) proposed an identification method and modeling of friction forces at the prismatic joints ofa 6 degrees-of-freedom (d.f.) hydraulically powered parallel link manipulator. Friction compensation method based on a nonlinear friction model whose parameters were estimated by nonlinear optimization was developed for a 2 d.f. planar parallel manipulator (Shang et al., 2008). Kemal and Tomizuka (2007) reviewed different friction modeling and compensation schemes, and proposed neural network based hybrid compensation methods, as well as experimentation tested on a direct drive servo mechanism, assuming the inertial dynamics were constant. Mostefai et al. (2010) presented a new methodology for the design of a robust controller to compensate for friction-induced dynamical characteristics inherently present in servo-drive systems and developed a friction model using a local modeling approach of the physical properties of friction along the operating range of the underlying system.

Backlash is common in mechanical and hydraulic systems, as the transmission part between the actuator and the measuring element of the system generally has backlash nonlinearity, which will not only increase the static error but also affect the system performance. Because the backlash has multi-value, it is very difficult to be exactly measured or mathematically written, as described by Chao et al. (2001). Grundelius and Angeli (1996) discussed two different adaptive controllers based on a backlash inverse and a linear controller for systems with backlash acting on the input, and the unknown parameters were estimated for the pole placement design of the linear controller and for backlash compensation in the backlash inverse. Campos et al. (2004) designed a dynamics inversion compensation scheme by using a filtered prediction for control of nonlinear discrete-time systems with input backlash, and showed how to use a neural network for inverting the backlash nonlinearity in the feed-forward path. Jang and Jeon (2006) designed a backlash compensator for nonlinear systems using fuzzy logic whose parameters were given by a tuning algorithm for the rejection of errors induced by the backlash, which had regions in which it behaved differently, guaranteeing small tracking errors and bounded parameter estimates. A dynamic fuzzy logic-based adaptive algorithm, an online identification and indirect adaptive control, in which the control input was adjusted adaptively to compensate the effect of nonlinearities, was proposed for reducing the effect of stick-slip friction and for the compensation of backlash, and a tuning algorithm for fuzzy logic parameters was used to ensure stable performance by Suraneni et al. (2005).

Compensation methods for nonlinearities of dead-zone, backlash and friction, either connect an inverse model before the nonlinearity, requiring an identification algorithm to acquire characteristics and parameters of the nonlinearity. However, developing a faithful model for physical nonlinearities is still a challenging task that is strongly related to the identification required by the structure of the model and the complexity of the control algorithm; or using certain algorithms which are usually intelligent algorithms, such as neural network, fuzzy control, and so on, to achieve an auxiliary control value used to compensate the nonlinearity. The former method is similar to adaptive inverse control. But no matter which method is applied for compensating nonlinear characteristics, the algorithm itself is rather complicated, and it is necessary to guarantee the algorithm convergence.What is more, it also affects the system stability. Though a certain nonlinearity can be compensated, the impact of the remaining nonlinear phenomena still exists.

Classical approaches, like PID regulators, have been widely applied in hydraulic systems, but they do not give a satisfactory performance under the nonlinear conditions. The electro-hydraulic servo system to be investigated here is a symmetric cylinder controlled by a symmetric valve system. In the simulation, by assuming that the actuator can be linearly modeled as a third-order system, the dynamic model of the hydraulic system is described as a serial connection of a static dead-zone nonlinearity and a linear system. In the simulation and experiments, both the results contain harmonics.

Power electronic devices have been widely used in industrial applications and transmissions or in distribution systems, such as static power inverters, adjustable motor drives and switching supplies (Chen et al., 1997). The nonlinear loads results in harmonic contamination that often causes problems to neighboring loads and tends to corrupt the overall quality of the provided power. A shunt passive filter, consisting of tuned LC (inductance capacitance, LC) filters, has been used to eliminate harmonics in power systems by providing impedance at a tuned frequency that the source impedance.However, its practical application has some problems, as described by Carlos (1998). To overcome those problems, the active power filter (APF) has been researched and developed. For the operation of APF, it detects the undesired harmonic components of current or voltage, then injects harmonics of equal magnitude but opposite phase, thereby canceling the original distortion. In recent years, various APF configurations with respective control strategies have been proposed (Chang and Shee, 2004; Chaoui et al., 2010; Jain et al., 2010; Nguyen et al., 2010). Blasko (1998) applied the adaptive noise cancelling method as a basis for the development of the adaptive selection harmonic cancelling algorithm to eliminate higher harmonics from the input utility current. However, the algorithm can only reduce higher selected harmonics. So the harmonic cancelling methods used in power system cannot be directly applied for a hydraulic system to cancel its harmonics.

Inspired by the development of active noise control technology, a new approach based on adaptive notch filter is applied to cancel the harmonic at the system output by adding harmonic to the controller command waveform with just the right phase and amplitude. The idea of the method is to add a reference harmonic to cancel harmonic in the system response. This is called “Adaptive Harmonic Cancellation”.

sec.p:

sec.title: 4. Application of the adaptive notch filter in harmonic cancellation
sec.p: When nonlinearities are present in a feedback control systems, spurious harmonics appear in the feedback even when the command is a simple sinusoid. This is especially true to the electro-hydraulic servo system shown in Figure 2. One way to reduce the harmonic distortion is to increase the controller feedback gain. This tends to linearize the nonlinearity, but the gain can be increased only before instability occurs. So in real application, this method cannot greatly reduce the harmonic distortion.

Inspired by active noise control technology, a new approach based on the adaptive notch filter is to add harmonics to the controller command waveform to cancel the harmonic at the system acceleration output. This technique is shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Acceleration harmonic cancellation.

In Figure 6, the dashed box is the harmonic cancellation. The task of harmonic cancellation is typically accomplished by generating a reference signal with the frequency of harmonic that should be eliminated from the output; moreover, it is filtered by the adaptive notch filter in such a way that it closely matches the harmonic. The output of the adaptive notch filter is a harmonic replica signal with the right phase and magnitude, and is added to the input signal,r, then cancelled harmonic from the output leaving the desired signal alone. The error between the input and the feedback contains harmonic information including phase and magnitude. The weights of the acceleration harmonic cancellation are updated by the error.

The adaptive notch filter is a network having two inputs and a single output which is the dot product of input xand the weight vector w. The input/output relationship of the adaptive filter is linear at any given time. However, when its weights are adjusted on-line, the relationship between the input/output signals, as a function of time, is no longer linear. The nonlinear adaptation of the weight vector for the adaptive filter is performed leads to an accurate harmonic elimination. The learning parameter α is also adapted for fast convergence. The main advantage of the adaptive notch filter architecture is the on-line adjusting ability and simplicity.

sec.title: 6. Experimental results
sec.p:
The electro-hydraulic servo shaking table used to validate the proposed control scheme is shown in Figure 9. It is a symmetric cylinder controlled by an FF102 servo valve, which is a two-stage symmetric servo valve. The system sample time is 1 ms. The oil supply pressure is 8 MPa. The cylinder has a stroke of 50 mm, and its piston and rod are Ф40 mm and Ф35 mm, respectively. To extend the acceleration frequency band and improve the system stability, a three-variable control strategy is applied. Figure 9.
Electro-hydraulic servo shaking table.

Its acceleration response is shown in Figure 10(a) as its time domain response, when the input acceleration is 3sin(2π × 8t)m/s2. Figure 10(b) is the equivalent of Figure 10(a) in the frequency domain. Figure 10.
Acceleration response before harmonic cancellation.

From Figure 10 it can be seen clearly that the acceleration output is distorted severely. It is shown that there are higher harmonics: second harmonic (at 16 Hz), third harmonic (at 24 Hz) and fourth harmonic (at 32 Hz), which cause the acceleration output distortion. The total harmonic distortion (THD)[3] percentage is 36.21%. Clearly, the third harmonic is in dominance.

Figure 11(a) shows the acceleration response of the shaking table after third harmonic cancellation with zero initial conditions and α = 0.01. Figure 11(b) is the equivalent in the frequency domain. Note that the third harmonic is well cancelled. The other harmonics are also in existence, so the acceleration curve in time domain is not very smooth, but greatly improved compared with that in Figure 10. The THD is reduced to 11.23%. The THD after third harmonic cancellation is greatly reduced comparing it to 36.21%. The comparison of frequency spectrums between Figure 10(b) and Figure 11(b) clearly shows over 50 dB of cancellation for the 24 Hz. Figure 11.
Acceleration output after third harmonic cancellation.

The weight values of the adaptive notch filter, which are time dependent, are plotted together in Figure 12. The initial values of the weights are all set to zeros. From this figure it is seen that the steady state is reached within 6 s. Figure 12.
Weights of the adaptive notch filter.

When the second and third harmonics are simultaneously cancelled for the electro-hydraulic servo shaking table, for the second harmonic cancellation, the input vector is x = [sin(32πt) cos(32πt)]T. The synthetical magnitude response of the harmonic cancellation is shown in Figure 13. It generates two notches at the frequencies 16 Hz and 24 Hz. Figure 13.

Figure 14(a) is the acceleration response with its input acceleration signal, and Figure 14(b) is its frequency spectrum. Compared to Figure 11(a), it can be seen that the acceleration response is further improved. From Figure 14(b), the second and third harmonics of the acceleration response are simultaneously eliminated with good efficiency. From Figure 11(b) and Figure 14(b), it is clearly shown that the cancellation for the 16 Hz is over 40 dB. The THD after second and third harmonic cancellation is 5.26%. Figure 14.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: Because nonlinearities occur in electro-hydraulic servo system with acceleration control, the acceleration output of the system corresponding to a sinusoidal input contains higher harmonics, which severely distort the acceleration signal. The results presented here have provided a new approach to solve the problem using an adaptive notch filter. Analysis of the adaptive filter and the adaptive algorithm are given. There are significant time-varying components in the filter weights. In the application, a tunable adaptive notch filter makes the reference exactly match the acceleration harmonic.

Nonlinearities are complex and are difficult to precisely model. For simplicity, a dead-zone nonlinear is considered in the simulation for a hydraulic servo control system. However, the efficiency of acceleration harmonic cancellation for real application is not influenced. Experimental results on a hydraulic shaking table clearly demonstrate the capability and validity of the control scheme in harmonic cancellation.

In the experiments, after second and third harmonic cancellation, though the fourth harmonic still exists, theTHD is very small. The THD is a very important criterion in real applications, so harmonics can be selected to be cancelled such that the THD value can meet practical requirements.

It should be noted that the added notch filter alters the original closed loop characteristics. The zeros on the unit circle result in a very sharp notches at the reference frequencies, and at other frequencies the magnitude response is essentially flat. Making a notch within or near the system bandwidth can influence the stability margin of the system at frequencies near harmonic frequency because of the associated changes in phase. So in real application, its parameters should be chosen properly.
